TermArray.name: DNA
TermArray.definition: Molecule/ material that carries genetic instructions in nearly all living things, comprised of nucleotides (designated A,C,G,T) and passed to offspring

TermArray.name: Genes
TermArray.definition: Fundamental physical and functional units of heredity which carry information from one generation to the next

TermArray.name: Chromosomes
TermArray.definition: Organized package of DNA bearing genes along its length.

TermArray.name: Genome
TermArray.definition: Entire set of DNA instructions in a cell

TermArray.name: Allele
TermArray.definition: A particular variant of a locus differing in DNA nucleotide sequence from other variants of the same locus

TermArray.name: Phenotype
TermArray.definition: An individual's observable traits

TermArray.name: Genotype
TermArray.definition: The combination of alleles found in an individual

TermArray.name: Locus
TermArray.definition: The specific physical or recombinational location of a gene or other particular DNA sequence on a chromosome

TermArray.name: Incomplete dominance
TermArray.definition: The situation wherein the phenotype of the heterozygous genotype (e.g., Bb) is distinct from and often intermediate to the phenotypes of the homozygous genotypes (BB and bb)

TermArray.name: Mitosis
TermArray.definition: The process where a cell divides and produces two daughter cells that are exact copies of the original

TermArray.name: Meiosis
TermArray.definition: The process for forming gametes (sperm or egg) wherein the daughter cells only receive half the genetic information of the parent cell

TermArray.name: Phase
TermArray.definition: Term identifying the combination of alleles across multiple genes that an individual received from one parent as separate from the combination of alleles an individual got from the other parent

TermArray.name: Linkage disequilibrium
TermArray.definition: Occurrence of an association of alleles more frequently than expected from random chance or independent assortment

TermArray.name: SNP
TermArray.definition: A position in a genome's DNA sequence wherein a single nucleotide -- A, C, G, or T -- differs among some members of a species

TermArray.name: Crossing Over
TermArray.definition: The swapping of genetic material between homologs of a single chromosome that occurs during meiosis

TermArray.name: Independent assortment
TermArray.definition: The process of random segregation of alleles at two loci into gametes, as what typically happens with alleles of genes on different chromosomes

TermArray.name: Quantitative trait
TermArray.definition: A trait whose natural variation is often continuous and is caused by allelic variation at many genes (as well as the environment)

TermArray.name: Quantitative trait locus (QTL)
TermArray.definition: Inferred location of one or more genes with genotypic variation affecting trait variation. It is a strong hypothesis of the location of a gene, based on results of genetic mapping

TermArray.name: LOD score
TermArray.definition: A measure of the statistical significance of association, e.g., between markers at/ near a location in the genome and the trait being studied

TermArray.name: Marker
TermArray.definition: Site of known/ relative location in the genome that is used for genetic mapping, e.g., to infer the location of a trait (or QTL)

TermArray.name: Power
TermArray.definition: The likelihood with which you'll detect an effect associated with alleles at a gene affecting a trait as a statistically significant QTL

TermArray.name: Linkage
TermArray.definition: A nonrandom association in the inheritance of alleles from two loci, typically ones near each other. The alleles do not assort independently.

TermArray.name: Epistasis
TermArray.definition: An interaction between genes such that the phenotypic effect of substituting genotypes at one gene is different depending on the genotype at another gene

TermArray.name: Incomplete penetrance
TermArray.definition: Some individuals bearing a particular genotype fail to express the phenotype normally associated with that genotype

TermArray.name: Codon
TermArray.definition: Trinucleotide sequence of DNA or RNA that specifies an amino acid

TermArray.name: Intron
TermArray.definition: Sequence interrupting a gene that does not code for an amino acid and is removed before the RNA sequence is used as a template for a protein

TermArray.name: Autosome
TermArray.definition: A chromosome that is inherited in the same manner in/ by the two sexes

TermArray.name: Sex chromosome
TermArray.definition: A chromosome that is inherited differently in/ by the two sexes

TermArray.name: Transcription
TermArray.definition: The process of making an RNA copy of a DNA template

TermArray.name: Translation
TermArray.definition: Using an RNA sequence as a template to produce a specific sequence of amino acids in a protein

TermArray.name: Fertilization
TermArray.definition: Union of male and female gametes to form a zygote
